ilo: Describe and analyse contemporary educational research and theory in social and emotional development and wellbeing.

Critically reflect independently and with colleagues on the development of their own social and emotional wellbeing capabilities and assess the implications for their work with children/ young people and communities.
Analyse safe and supportive learning environments using knowledge of evidence-based approaches to promote social and emotional development and wellbeing.
Illustrate the conditions, connections and relationships that lead to strong development and learning.
Articulate the importance of working within regulatory frameworks governing to support children's social and emotional wellbeing.
generic_skills: Responsiveness to a changing knowledge base.

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Presentation: Create and present a lesson on social and emotional well-being (1500 words equivalent)
Reflection: Written reflection on understandings of learning environments
Professional Plan: Design a partnership plan to support social and emotional well-being

assessment.hurdle: Teacher Candidates must provide written peer feedback on least one or more classmates' presenations.
A minimum of 80% attendance at, or engagement with, all sessions identified as contact hours (may include lectures, tutorials, seminars and workshops, both synchronous and asynchronous).

date_times.contact_hours: 24 hours (16 hours of on-campus classes and 8 hours of asynchronous online activities)
